lesson.title: If it is sunny I will go

description.content: In this lesson we will practise sentences with conditional clauses. We will look at various phrases which can be used to mark a clause as conditional and attach it to a sentence, and the different nuances that these words carry. In this lesson you will be given two pictures, one depicting the conditional clause and the other depicting the sentence, and asked to choose the the correct grammar pattern to connect them. The main forms to be practised in this lesson are summarised by the following examples.

japanese.content: 暇なら教会に行こう
ひまならきょうかいへいこう
hima nara kyoukai he ikou

translated.content: If you are free, let's go to the church.

japanese.content: 明日暇なら銀行に行きます
あすひまならぎんこうにいきます
asu hima nara ginkou ni ikimasu

translated.content: If I am free tomorrow, I will go to the bank.

japanese.content: 雨が降ったら出かけない。
あめがふったらでかけない
ame ga hut tara dekakenai

translated.content: If it rains, we won't go out.

japanese.content: 宿題が終わったら遊ぼう
しゅくだいがおわったらあそぼう
shukudai ga owat tara asobou

translated.content: When we finish the homework, let's go play outdoors.

japanese.content: 春になると暖かくなる
はるになるとあたたかくなる
haru ni naru to atatakaku naru

translated.content: When Spring comes, it becomes warm.

japanese.content: 秋になると涼しくなる。
あきになるとすずしくなる
aki ni naru to suzushiku naru

translated.content: When Autumn comes, it becomes cool.

japanese.content: 病院まで歩けば近い
びょういんまであるけばちかい
byouin made aruke ba tikai.

translated.content: The hospital is close if you walk.

japanese.content: 図書館まで歩けば遠い
としょかんまであるけば遠い
toshokan made aruke ba tooi.

translated.content: The library is far if you walk.

grammar_points.p: When the word "nara" is used to mark a conditional statement, the emphasis of the sentence is on the speaker's belief in the truth of the condition, and you can think of it as giving the necessary conditions for the main sentence to be true. In other words, the emphasis is on the speaker's assumption. The word "nara" must be directly preceded by a noun, or a verb. Verbs are optionally followed by the noun marker "no".
Examples:
明日なら時間があります - "If it's tomorrow, I'm free."
みんなが行くのなら私も行きます - "If everyone goes, I will go too."

In the first example, the speaker implies that tomorrow is the only day that he is free. Similarly, in the second sentence the speaker implies that everyone going is a condition for him, and he will not go under other circumstances.

Next, we will look at a more general way to form conditional sentences. In this case, the conditional clause is marked by a verb in the "tara" form. This form is constructed by adding the sound "ra" to the plain past form of the verb. Study the examples in the chart below. Unlike sentences with "nara", more emphasis is placed on the result than the condition.

When a conditional clause is marked with "tara", it must be the case that the condition occurs or becomes true before the event described in the main clause of the sentence. In other words, the condition is completed or fulfilled before the result happens in the sequential ordering of events. The main sentence that occurs after the condition is usually used to express a conclusion or result, but it can also express the speaker's volition, make a request to the listener, or permit or prohibit an action.
Examples:
勉強が終わったらコーヒーを飲みましょう - "When I'm done studying, let's drink some coffee."
雨が降ったら傘を買います - "If it rains, I will buy an umbrella."

Note that "tara" is ambiguous depending on the truth of the condition. When the condition is certain (or very likely), "tara" is translated as "when", but if the truth of the condition is not known (or cannot be known) "tara" is translated as "if".

When "to" directly follows the dictionary form of a verb, it marks a conditional clause. In this case, the conclusion or resulting state indicated by the main clause is an uncontrollable result. In other words, it must be a natural conclusion or certain fact (or one that the speaker is convinced is true), and cannot be a suggestion or expression of the speaker's volition. Because of this restriction, "to" cannot be used for giving suggestions or expressing the speaker's volition.
Examples:
冬になると雪が降ります - "Whenever the winter comes, it snows."
先生に聞かないとわかりません - "If I don't ask the professor, I won't know." ("I won't know unless I ask the professor.")

Finally, we will consider a way to make general conditional statements. The "ba" form of a verb is used to indicate a simple conditional statement followed by a result, with no special implications. It lacks the restriction to uncontrollable outcomes implied by "to", the completion of the condition and strict ordering implied by "tara", and the focus on the speaker's belief in the condition that "nara" gives. It is the most general way to indicate a hypothetical situation, and gives the sentence an objective nuance.
Examples:
東京に行けば楽しいです - "You will have fun if you go to Tokyo."
先生に聞けばわかります - "You will understand if you ask the professor."
To construct this form, start with the dictionary form and change the final "u" sound to "e" and add "ba". See the chart below for examples.
In general, the main sentence that follows the conditional marked with "ba" cannot be used for giving suggestions, granting permission, or expressing the speaker's volition.
